topics.title: Why funnels and MQLs/SQLs are flawed
topics.summary: Gia explains why funnels, pirate metrics, and lead labels (MQL/SQL) are often meaningless, business-centric, and ignore the full SaaS lifecycle (retention/expansion) and the pre-solution “problem stage.”

topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces the podcast and Gia Laudi, previewing a practical process for finding growth opportunities via customer journeys, goals, and execution.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages: Amplitude (product analytics, experimentation, CDP) and Athletic Greens AG1 (daily nutrition supplement).

topics.title: Gia’s career journey and Forget The Funnel
topics.summary: Gia summarizes her marketing background (retail, freelancing, Unbounce) and how she and Claire Suellentrop formed Forget The Funnel to help B2B SaaS teams with customer research and growth strategy.

topics.title: Why the consultancy is called Forget The Funnel
topics.summary: Gia expands on why funnels feel misaligned: they bucket customers, center the business over customer value, omit the pre-discovery context, and underweight post-acquisition in recurring-revenue SaaS.

topics.title: Typical growth impact: messaging, onboarding, activation
topics.summary: Gia shares common outcomes from their work—ideal-customer realignment, stronger positioning/messaging, and onboarding improvements—citing examples like 89% website conversion lift and 40% trial-to-paid lift from better-fit signups.

topics.title: How common are “double conversion” opportunities?
topics.summary: Gia argues most companies have major latent opportunities, especially in the messy ownership area of onboarding/activation, and that every engagement yields actionable customer insights.

topics.title: Airbnb storyboard moment: customer-journey alignment
topics.summary: Gia recounts seeing Airbnb’s storyboarded customer journey (including emotions and off-platform context), which inspired Unbounce leaders to build a shared, customer-centered map that improved cross-team alignment and execution.

topics.title: Process overview and SparkToro case setup
topics.summary: Gia outlines the high-level method: understand best customers, map their value journey, make it measurable, and find misalignments—then introduces SparkToro’s challenge: strong traffic/signups but weak free-to-paid conversion.

topics.title: Jobs-to-be-done research: surveys and best-customer criteria
topics.summary: Using JTBD, Gia explains surveying recent, happy paying customers (3–6 months) to uncover triggers, anxieties, must-haves, and desired outcomes—often sufficient without interviews when patterns are clear.

topics.title: Choosing which customer job to prioritize
topics.summary: Gia describes how to pick a primary job: willingness to pay, urgency (painkiller vs vitamin), retention/expansion potential, market reachability, and “unfair advantage,” plus clarifies you can serve secondary jobs later.

topics.title: From data to strategy: avoid tactical piecemeal growth
topics.summary: They contrast tactical conversion tweaking with a customer-led approach: use data to spot issues, but zoom out to define the ideal customer/job first so acquisition and onboarding bring better-fit users through the door.

topics.title: Mapping the customer journey into milestones
topics.summary: Gia explains journey mapping as a “how I met and fell in love with your product” story, typically spanning struggle (problem/interest), evaluation (first value, value realization), and growth (habit, expansion).

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor message: Maven cohort-based courses for product, leadership, branding, marketing, and decision-making.

topics.title: Operationalizing the map: KPIs, activation, win-backs
topics.summary: Gia details attaching KPIs to each milestone (website visitors, CTA conversion, activation/engagement), using research to front-load key value features, and building proactive onboarding plus reactive re-engagement when users fall off.

topics.title: SparkToro KPI examples for activation and value
topics.summary: They walk through concrete SparkToro milestones and metrics: first search as an evaluation trigger, then activation via multiple searches plus creating lists, and deeper value via searches + lists + exporting.
